docs.Title: Super Mario Maker 2 Review
docs.Content: Co-op play is also kind of confusing. It's well-known you can't play online with your friends, at least not right away. But what you CAN do is play with your friends on another Switch if you're all in the same room (or close enough to connect to one another).

docs.Title: Spelunky 2 Review
docs.Content: (Spelunky 2 also features online multiplayer, though the servers weren’t available at the time of this review, so unfortunately, I wasn’t able to test it out. Instead, we made use of Steam's Remote Play feature to simulate local co-op.)

docs.Title: Dawn of Discovery: Venice Review
docs.Content: However, their impact will certainly be felt more in PVP when strategies become less predictable. While there are features such as a new quest type called "Trade Race" that add to the single player game, most of the changes compliment the new player vs. player and co-op online modes.

docs.Title: LittleBigPlanet UK Review
docs.Content: Surprisingly though, cooperative play perhaps isn't as significant a focus as you might expect. While there's the occasional nod to objective-based co-op, with certain levels featuring puzzles requiring a specific number of players to complete, it's an underutilised element of the game and rewards are generally slight. LittleBigPlanet's multiplayer appeal lies in the community experience itself, relying heavily on the game's innately hilarious mayhem as players thrust, dance, collect, accessorise or ricochet to their goal.

docs.Title: Overcooked 2 Review
docs.Content: All modes can also be played online with friends, and matchmaking is available for arcade and versus. While Overcooked 2 still feels right at home as a couch co-op experience, it’s nice to have the option to play online when you don’t have friends nearby. A word of warning, though: the Switch version does not have voice chat.

docs.Title: Diablo III Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 Review
docs.Content: Online co-op can be invite only, or drop-in/drop-out, and the ability to specifically seek partners for PvP or endgame key-warden content makes it easy to find a party that suits your mood. But as nice as that it is, nothing beats the four-player couch co-op. Transferring characters over via cloud, or USB is simple and painless, and no matter whose system you’re playing on, you get to keep what you find.

docs.Title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra Game Review
docs.Content: It's nice to be able to play with a buddy (why should one person suffer alone?), but online play is pretty standard these days. This is a full-priced retail game. It's ugly and not very satisfying; the least it could do is give gamers a feature-set equal to other titles.

docs.Title: MySims SkyHeroes Review
docs.Content: Dogfighting and racing are best when you've got lots of real people competing, and SkyHeroes supports up to four players locally and over the Nintendo Wi-Fi connection. There's nothing revolutionary about the multiplayer, but it can be fun if you don't mind the annoyances of the gameplay. At this point, though, unless you've already got long distance friends at the ready, online play doesn't seem to be much of an option.

docs.Title: TowerFall Ascension Review
docs.Content: Developer Matt Makes Games unfortunately didn’t include an online mode, and the single-player and co-op modes against waves of simple-minded enemies don’t stand out significantly except as practice. But TowerFall’s selection of match modifiers and over 120 maps allow you to tweak this couch-multiplayer game in fun ways that kept me and my friends playing and laughing for hours.

docs.Title: Boogie Bunnies Review
docs.Content: Multiplayer modes do fare a bit better, with cooperative local play and something that we think is supposed to be online adversarial matchups but that wasn't nearly as clear as it should have been. Co-op play is fine. You and a buddy inhabit the same three sides of the puzzle but you can't cross paths so you have to strategize with one another in order to be victorious.

docs.Title: Damnation Review
docs.Content:
The whole mechanic is clunky thanks to poor animations (Rourke can climb a motionless rope without using his legs -- his appendages just hang there lifelessly.). As if everything I just told you didn't completely turn you off to this title, you need to know that multiplayer is worthless here. Yes, you can play co-op online, but there's no voicechat so don't even think about discussing attack plans.

Yes, there are online versus matches, but you can't join a game in progress; you just spectate until the kill limit is reached or the time limit expires. Yes, very few people are playing this game, but the maps don't adjust to the number of players; enjoy running around a huge map with one other person! The framerate is bad here, but it's just as bad as it is when you're by yourself so I guess that's good for this game.

docs.Title: MLB The Show 22 Review
docs.Content:
Double Play Online co-op is one of the key new editions in 2022, allowing you to form teams for 2v2 or 3v3 competition across platforms either with friends or through random matchmaking. Players on each team alternate batters while at the plate and rotate between pitching and fielding each inning, and being able to focus single-mindedly on one defensive task is liberating. While one person plays cat and mouse with pitch selection, the other can focus on where to go for force outs and make strategic choices around the diamond.

In its current iteration, co-op feels more like a fun proof-of-concept rather than a fully fleshed-out mode fit for online competition. The stability I’ve come to expect from The Show has taken a noticeable hit. “ Co-op games frequently failed to connect me with cross-platform friends when we tried to play together as well, and all sorts of technical issues were unfortunately common in my time with The Show 22.

docs.Title: LittleBigPlanet: Game of the Year Edition Review
docs.Content: You'll come across sections that require two (or in a couple cases, three or four) other players in order to nab all the goodies. Fortunately, even if you don't have any friends, finding others to play with you online is as simple as choosing to "Play Online" instead of by yourself at the start of each level. Bam, instant multiplayer game.

docs.Title: Homeworld 3 Multiplayer Review
docs.Content:
Homeworld has a long, proud history of mods that includes some of the finest Star Wars and Star Trek (among others) total conversions ever created, and I look forward to that tradition carrying forward.

This review covers the multiplayer modes of Homeworld 3. For thoughts on the multiplayer skirmish and War Games co-op mode, see the Homeworld 3 Single-Player Campaign review . When coming up with a real-time strategy game's multiplayer modes, a developer generally has two options: let us play with all of the toys in an all-out brawl until the other side is dead, with maybe a few minor twists thrown in, or try something new, different, and a little risky.

docs.Title: Wargroove Review
docs.Content: “ Arcade is good preparation for a similar setup in PvP, too, and Wargroove’s options are pretty much the gold standard for multiplayer turn-based strategy games. Local play with up to four players works well enough, especially for co-op maps, but the online options are what’s really impressive: Wargroove has cross-play for PC, Switch, and Xbox One, including map sharing – though, surprising no one, Chucklefish says there will be no cross-platform support for the PS4 version when it launches there later this year.

docs.Title: Grand Theft Auto IV PS3 Review
docs.Content: These three "modes" are missions similar to what you might experience in the single-player game. Niko doesn't exist in multiplayer, but you still get cut-scenes and some unique dialogue wrapped around some fun missions. Co-op supports up to four players and only has some minor variables.

docs.Title: Grand Theft Auto IV Xbox 360 Review
docs.Content: These three "modes" are missions similar to what you might experience in the single-player game. Niko doesn't exist in multiplayer, but you still get cut-scenes and some unique dialogue wrapped around some fun missions. Co-op supports up to four players and only has some minor variables.

docs.Title: Team Sonic Racing Review
docs.Content: Multiplayer has all the options you’d expect, from custom friend lobbies to matchmaking and even ranked matches. Local multiplayer is just as flexible. Coordinating a team of three racers online is extremely satisfying to pull off, but introduces brand new challenges most arcade racing fans haven’t dealt with before in terms of communication, bringing much-needed shake-up to the genre as a whole.

docs.Title: Let's Golf! 2 iPhone Review
docs.Content: 2 also has a nice online multiplayer game (WiFi only) that lets you compete with friends. Unfortunately, this has come at the expense of "hot seat" multiplayer where you pass the phone back and forth. This is not a tremendous loss to me as that's just not how I spend my in-person time with friends, but I've seen some grumbling online over it.

docs.Title: Watchmen: The End is Nigh Review
docs.Content: Co-op play doesn't actually add very much to the experience. It's nice to be able to enjoy Watchmen on a couch with a buddy -- as much as one can enjoy this game -- but online play is where it's at these days. Offline only cooperative games are a thing of the past and a $20 downloadable game needs to offer online play.

docs.Title: Scramble Review
docs.Content: This co-op may be strange, but even more mind numbing is the fact that you can't play it offline. Although the ability to include this is clearly there since you can do it online, you can only play a multiplayer game offline by trading turns. There's also an online versus mode.

docs.Title: Destiny Review
docs.Content: The competitive multiplayer, called The Crucible, is the chief example of this. The few included maps do sport Bungie's hallmark map design - they’re excellent, in fact. But without private lobbies to organize fights with friends, or any ways to customize the handful of game modes, it’s hard to imagine the multiplayer shooter enthusiast who could be satisfied with it.

docs.Title: Black Desert Online Review
docs.Content: The loop in the catch-rope I cast is laughably too small, for instance, and I can't even tell the gender of the horse for breeding it with other horses until I've caught it. But there's always a moment of quiet joy when I managed to win one over with a handful of sugar. I can think of no other contemporary massively multiplayer online RPG that grants me that same satisfaction.

docs.Title: Guncraft Review
docs.Content: Siege, for instance, has two teams build bases while attacking the opponents’, but more often than not both sides duked it out in the middle and ignored crafting for the most part until the clock ran out. Spleef—a mode in which players knock blocks out from under each other to send enemies falling to their deaths—lost its appeal after a mere 30 seconds due to the sporadic and inconsistent scoring system, making me think it’d be more at home in the next Mario Party than as its own game type. The Gears of War Horde clone, dubbed Onslaught, is a decent co-op experience, though the lack of in-game voice chat (beyond Steam’s built-in VOIP) makes teamwork difficult.

docs.Title: Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War Zombies Review
docs.Content: Servers have been stable since shortly after launch, so at least you can expect online play to be smooth, but having to buy a second copy (to say nothing of a whole second gaming system) just to play with someone in your own home stings a bit. Additionally, previously you could play through Zombies solo but with AI-controlled companions that would help fight off the hordes and revive you when you got downed – they just couldn’t complete objectives. That’s missing now, and I could only find the option for matchmaking online or very lonely solo.

docs.Title: Sniper Elite III Review
docs.Content: In fact, two of the standout modes are Distance King and No Cross, which respectively reward teams based on the range of their kills, and separate them with impassable barriers meant to force them to snipe. These modes are enjoyable, but they're not fundamentally different from what you'd find in any other online shooter. Co-op, on the other hand, is much more rewarding.
